benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/tags - Retrieve account tags

covered: Valid Request: TC01, TC02, TC03, TC04, TC05 and related scenarios exercise successful retrieval and the primary combinations of includedDeleted and audit parameters returning 200 and JSON arrays.
Empty Response: TC06 verifies behavior when an account has no tags (empty JSON array).
Path parameter validation & error responses: TC07 (404), TC08 (400) and TC20-TC23 cover non-existent accounts, invalid UUID format, partial UUIDs, empty and whitespace accountId edge cases.
Query parameter validation: TC02-TC05, TC09, and TC10 validate accepted audit values, includedDeleted behavior, invalid audit values, and handling of unknown parameters.
Authentication errors: TC12 and TC13 cover missing and invalid authentication leading to 401 responses.
Security input validation: TC14 and TC15 check for SQL injection and XSS-style inputs and expect 400 responses.
Performance & concurrency: TC16 and TC17 cover large payload handling (10,000 tags) and concurrent request behavior, including performance expectations.
Integration & resilience: TC11, TC24, and TC25 cover API unavailability, downstream service failures (503/502), and cross-system data consistency.
Regression & compatibility: TC18 and TC19 are regression/back-compat checks to ensure previously fixed behaviors and legacy client compatibility remain intact.
gaps: Pagination: No tests address pagination (page/limit, offsets) or behavior for paged results — important for large datasets.
Caching behavior: No tests verify caching headers (ETag, Cache-Control) or conditional GET semantics (If-None-Match -> 304).
Rate limiting/throttling: No tests exercise rate-limiting behavior or 429 responses when limits are exceeded.
Schema validation for Tag objects: Tests assert "Tag objects" are returned but do not validate Tag schema (required fields, data types, enum constraints).
Forbidden/403 scenarios: No tests for authenticated-but-unauthorized access (403) or role-based permission checks.
Content-Type and media negotiation checks: Content-Type is asserted only in TC01; other successful scenarios do not assert response headers or Accept negotiation.
Boolean parameter negative tests: No tests for malformed boolean values for includedDeleted (e.g., includedDeleted=notABool) to confirm 400 handling.
Error body consistency: Tests check error status codes but do not assert a standardized error response structure (code/message/details).

Distinction between concurrency and rate-limit failure: TC17 tests concurrent success but does not validate behavior when concurrency crosses configured throttling thresholds resulting in 429/503 etc.

Pagination-related performance/streaming: Large dataset performance is tested (10,000 tags) but there are no tests for chunked/streamed responses or server behavior when result size is extremely large.
recommendations: Add pagination tests if the API supports paging: validate page/limit parameters, boundary conditions (first/last page), out-of-range pages, and consistent ordering; if the API does not support paging, add an explicit test documenting and asserting that behavior.
Add caching tests: assert presence of Cache-Control and ETag headers; implement conditional GET tests using If-None-Match to verify 304 responses when appropriate.
Add rate-limiting/throttling tests: simulate rapid request bursts to validate configured limits and expected 429 responses and Retry-After headers.
Add JSON schema assertions for Tag objects across all successful tests (required fields, types, allowed enum values for audit-related fields) to ensure payload correctness.
Introduce 403 tests for authenticated users lacking permissions (role-based access) if applicable to the system.
Assert Content-Type and other relevant headers (Content-Length, charset) in all successful responses and add Accept header negotiation tests.
Add negative tests for malformed includedDeleted and other query parameter type mismatches to ensure clear 400 responses.
Standardize and assert error response body structure for 400/401/403/404/5xx scenarios to improve client-side error handling and testability.
For very large result sets, either add pagination or streaming tests; if returning all items is intended, add tests that validate memory/response size limits and graceful degradation/failure modes.
Separate concurrency performance tests from rate-limiting tests: verify that the system both handles expected concurrent load and properly rejects/limits requests beyond configured thresholds.
